__EMPTY_1:
A general note on comparitive Adverbs: (This statement isn’t fully correct, consider dobrze, nigdy etc. Needs remodelling)
Generally, if the ad-word ends with -szy it’s an adjective. If it ends with -iej or -o then it’s an adverb.
The addition of -iej will usually indicate ‘more’ of the adverb. Eg szybciej = More quickly (faster). -o or -ie would be the base of the adverb. -iej is the comparitive form of an adverb, whereas -o is the basic form.
Examples:
On jest szybszy niż ona – He is faster than her >>>> Adjective >>>> We are describing the noun ‘On’
On biega szybciej niż ona >>>> Adverb >>>> We are describing the verb ‘Biega’
Adverbs are also used to describe a state or a situation.
Words like dzisiaj, wczoraj, jutro etc are not nouns, they’re adverbs of time. So for sentence construction, we treat them as impersonal constructs, so they would be described using an adverb in order to describe the general condition/state.
Examples:
Dzisiaj jest zimno >>>> This sentence is impersonal and features no nouns >>>> Adverb
Dzisiaj jest zimny dzień >>>> This sentence has the noun dzień >>>> Adjective
Can also mean ‘is allowed’. Generally, powoli is used to mean doing an action slowly
Likewise / same to you / each other
__EMPTY_2: Used to enforce mutuality of something, eg liking, respecting etc

Used to emphasise a verb, such as ‘Dzisiaj jest gorąco’, jest is the verb. As opposed to ‘To jest gorący dzień’, where what’s being described is a noun, therefor a regular adjective is needed. Adverb is also required to describe the ‘state’ of something, such as ‘today is hot’
Indicates presence in all places – ‘Problems exist everywhere’
used to describe actions or events that occurred before another point in time.
